Writing case studies is one of the best ways for me to zoom out and look at what I‚Äôve accomplished in my professional life. Here are some best practices I‚Äôve been using.

Write case studies when you don‚Äôt need them

I am well familiar with the dread of having to put together a design portfolio. It‚Äôs exciting once it‚Äôs live, but up until that point, it feels as though I‚Äôm a house painter, and my prospective clients come to my house to assess how well I‚Äôve done. I do my best to write case studies periodically, picking interesting features or processes in which I‚Äôve been involved recently.

Tell a compelling story

Rather than working to fill sections with technical and practical information (‚Äúthis was my role in the team‚Äù, ‚ÄúI used these methods‚Äù), I do my best to embed this content in a broader story. I don‚Äôt typically use the headings listed below, but these are the elements that make up any case study I write:

  • Background: things were giong great until we realized there was a problem for our customers
  • Conflict: this is the first time I‚Äôve ever done something like this, I wasn‚Äôt sure if I‚Äôd be able to do everything
  • Rising action: I tried many things, failed a bunch. I learned how important it is to continually iterate, get stakeholder feedback, and involve engineering early in the process
  • Climax: I wasn‚Äôt sure if we‚Äôd make it, but we did and it was a success
  • Failing action: by involving engineering early, we side-stepped a massive problem and forged new bonds for future projects
  • Resolution: the solution we built has been receiving mostly positive feedback from customers. We‚Äôll be iterating soon‚Ä¶

Let me know what you think I won't know you've been here unless you tell me. Let me know what you think about this either via email, Mastodon or webmention. I would love to read about your perspective.
